front.title: Internet Key Exchange Protocol Version 2 (IKEv2) Configuration for Encrypted DNS

abstract.t: This document specifies new Internet Key Exchange Protocol Version 2 (IKEv2) Configuration Payload Attribute Type(s) for encrypted DNS such as DNS-over-HTTPS (DoH) and DNS-over-TLS (DoT).

section.title: Introduction
section.t: This document specifies how an initiator can be configured with the Authentication Domain Name (ADN, defined in ) of DNS-over-HTTPS (DoH) or DNS-over-TLS (DoT) server using Internet Key Exchange Protocol Version 2 (IKEv2) .
Particularly, this document introduces new IKEv2 Configuration Payload Attribute Type(s) () and notification status types () for the support of DoT/DoT servers.
Sample use cases are discussed in . The Configuration Payload Attribute Type(s) defined in are not specific to these deployments, but can be used in other deployment contexts.

section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in BCP 14 when, and only when, they appear in all capitals, as shown here.
This document makes use of the terms defined in and .
Also, this document makes use of the terms defined in . In particular, readers should be familiar with "initiator" and "responder" terms used in that document.
'DoH/DoT' refers to DNS-over-HTTPS and/or DNS-over-TLS.

section.title: Consistent DNS Configuration of Cellular Devices via "Trusted" and "Untrusted" Access Networks
section.t: The 3rd Generation Partnership Project (3GPP) defines the notion of "trusted" and "untrusted" access networks . For an "untrusted" non-3GPP access, the UE establishes a connection to the core network (e.g., 5G core network) via the Non-3GPP InterWorking Function (N3IWF). To that aim, the UE performs registration to the core network during the Internet Key Exchange Protocol Version 2 (IKEv2) SA establishment procedure as specified in .

For example, when the UE attaches the network using a Wireless Local Area Network (WLAN) access by means of IKEv2 capabilities, the UE can be provided with an IPv4 address, an IPv6 prefix, a list of IP addresses of the DNS server. If the network supports DoT/DoH, there are no equivalent Configuration Payload Attribute Type(s) to the options defined in .

The support of DoT/DoH IKEv2 attributes is meant to ensure a coherent configuration for UEs independently of the access network used by an UE to attach the network. For example, an UE may attach first to an "untrusted" access network and then hand over to a "trusted" network.

section.title: INTERNAL_DNS_ADN Attribute
section.t: The INTERNAL_DNS_ADN attribute is used to configure an authentication domain name of the DoH/DoT server. The format of this attribute is shown in .
The fields of the attribute shown in are as follows:

list.t: R: Reserved bit; refer to Section 3.15.1 of .
Length: Length of the DNS Authentication Domain Name field in octets.

Authentication Domain Name: A fully qualified domain name of the DoH/DoT server following the syntax in . The name MUST NOT contain any terminators (e.g., NULL, CR). An example of valid ADN is "doh1.example.com".

section.title: URI Template
section.t: DoH servers may support more than one URI Template . The following sub-sections discuss some candidate solutions for a DoH client to retrieve the list of supported templates by a DoH server. Also, if the resolver hosts several DoH services (e.g., no-filtering, blocking adult content, blocking malware), these services can be discovered as templates.
This section will be updated to reflect the outcome of the discussion in .
How a DoH client makes use of the configured DoH services is out of scope of this document.

section.title: ENCRYPTED_DNS_ALLOWED and DO53_DISABLED Status Types
section.t: ENCRYPTED_DNS_ALLOWED and DO53_DISABLED status types are defined to inform the initiator about the responser's capabilities regarding the support of Do53, DoH, and DoT. These notification status types are used by the initiator to adjust its behavior ().
No data is associated with these notifications.

section.title: IKEv2 Protocol Exchange
section.t: This section describes how an initiator can be configured with the ADN of DoH/DoT server using IKEv2.

Initiators indicate the support of DoH/DoT in the CFG_REQUEST payloads by including INTERNAL_DNS_ADN attribute, while responders supply the DoT/DoH configuration in the CFG_REPLY payloads or instruct the initiator to initiate a DHCP exchange (INTERNAL_IP6_DHCP (or INTERNAL_IP4_DHCP)). Concretely:

list.t: If an INTERNAL_DNS_ADN attribute is included in the CFG_REQUEST, the initiator MUST also include INTERNAL_IP4_DNS and/or INTERNAL_IP6_DNS attributes in the CFG_REQUEST. In such case, the INTERNAL_DNS_ADN attribute MUST be empty.

If an INTERNAL_DNS_ADN is sent by the responder, the responder MUST also include one or more INTERNAL_IP4_DNS or INTERNAL_IP6_DNS attributes that contain the IPv4 or IPv6 address of the internal DNS server.
If the responder replies with INTERNAL_IP6_DHCP (or INTERNAL_IP4_DHCP), the initiator MUST follow the procedure defined in to retrieve the ADN of DoH/DoT server.

If the CFG_REQUEST includes an INTERNAL_DNS_ADN attribute but the CFG_REPLY does not include an INTERNAL_DNS_ADN attribute, this is an indication that DoT/DoH is not supported by the DNS server reachable at INTERNAL_IP4_DNS or INTERNAL_IP6_DNS.

If the CFG_REQUEST does not include an INTERNAL_DNS_ADN attribute, and absent any policy, the responder MAY reply with INTERNAL_IP4_DNS or INTERNAL_IP6_DNS attributes. If the responder supports DoT/DoH, it MAY include an ENCRYPTED_DNS_ALLOWED notification status to inform the initiator that its supports DoT/DoH. If the initiator didn't include INTERNAL_DNS_ADN attribute in the CFG_REQUEST, but receives ENCRYPTED_DNS_ALLOWED notification status from the responder, the initiator MAY send a request with the INTERNAL_DNS_ADN attribute.

If the CFG_REQUEST does not include an INTERNAL_DNS_ADN attribute and the responder only supports encrypted DNS, the responder MUST reply with DO53_DISABLED notification status. Upon receipt of such notification by a DoT/DoH capable initiator, it MUST send a request with the INTERNAL_DNS_ADN attribute.

section.t: The DNS client establishes a DoH/DoT session with the address(es) conveyed in INTERNAL_IP6_DNS (or INTERNAL_IP4_DNS) and uses the mechanism discussed in Section 8 of to authenticate the DNS server certificate using the authentication domain name conveyed in INTERNAL_DNS_ADN.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: This document adheres to the security considerations defined in . In particular, this document does not change the trust on the DNS configuration provided by a responder.
